questions.question: Which of the following is statements is false?

options.A: 90% of the cortisol is bound to plasma proteins
options.B: Cortisol has a half-life of 60-90 minutes.
options.C: Aldosterone has a half-life of about 20 minutes.
options.D: 80% of the aldosterone is bound to plasma proteins

questions.explanation: 60% of aldosterone is bound to plasma proteins, not 80%.90% of cortisol is bound to plasma proteins. Most of it is bound to transcortin, acorticosteroid-specific ° 2 globulin, and the rest to albumin. This high degree of binding to plasmaproteins slows the elimination of cortisol. Therefore, cortisol has a longer half-life of 60 to 90minutes.Since only about 60% of aldosterone is in bound form, it has a relatively short half-life of about 20minutes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an action of cortisol?
questions.explanation: Cortisol suppresses the proliferation of T-lymphocytes and decreases the number ofT-Lymphocytes.Actions of Cortisol:Metabolic effects:• Effect on carbohydrates: Exert an anti-insulin effect, leading to hyperglycemia• Increases gluconeogenesis•Increases glycogen synthesis••• Decreases utilization of glucose in peripheral tissues• Effect on fat and appetite: promotes mobilization of fatty acids from adipose tissue in acutestates. This mobilization increases the concentration of free fatty acids in the plasma, which alsoincreases their utilization for energy, causing lipolysis. However, in chronic states cortisolincreases appetite and food intake by inducing the synthesis of neuropeptide-Y which leads to anapparent lipogenic effect seen as buffalo humping and central obesity.• Effect on protein: Exerts a catabolic effect and causes proteolysis• Effect on water and electrolytes: Sodium water retention and diuresisAnti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects:• Induce the synthesis of lipocortin, an inhibitor of phospholipase A2• Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin• Inhibit the production of IL-2 and T lymphocytes, and depress cellular immunityMaintenance of vascular responsiveness to catecholamines:• Cortisol up-regulates ° 1 receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to the vasoconstrictoreffect of norepinephrine

questions.question: A 60-year-old man is being treated for severe COVID with dexamethasone. Which of thefollowing mechanisms best explain the rationale for starting steroids in this patient?
questions.explanation: Inhibition of phospholipase A2 is an anti-inflammatory effect of steroids, thus being the rationalefor starting steroids in this patient.Patients with severe COVID are at high risk of developing a systemic inflammatory response.Steroids help in mitigating these deleterious effects.Phospholipase A2 is a precursor of arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid is the precursor forprostaglandins and leukotrienes, which are involved in inflammation. Steroids induce thesynthesis of lipocortin, which inhibits phospholipase A2.Other anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects of steroids are:• Inhibit the production of interleukin-2 (IL-2) and proliferation of T lymphocytes•Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin from mast cells and platelets

questions.question: Which of the following effects is produced only at high levels of glucocorticoids?

options.B: Increased excretion of a water load

questions.explanation: Inhibition of inflammatory response requires high levels of glucocorticoids.Anti-inflammatory and anti-allergic responses (inhibition of histamine from mast cells andbasophils) are produced only at high levels of glucocorticoids. These effects cannot be produced bynormal circulating glucocorticoids in the body and thus require exogenous supplementation ofsteroids to produce them.737

questions.question: Which of the following has the greatest effect on plasma osmolality?
questions.explanation: Vasopressin (also called ADH or anti-diuretic hormone) has the greatest effect on plasmaosmolality.Two primary systems are especially involved in regulating the concentration of sodium andosmolarity of extracellular fluid:• The osmoreceptor-ADH system and• The thirst mechanism.Although aldosterone decreases the rate of sodium excretion by the kidneys, the concentration ofsodium in the extracellular fluid rises only by a few mEqs. The reason for this is that when sodiumis reabsorbed by the tubules, simultaneous absorption of equivalent amounts of water occurs.
